The theme of the PORGMUN 2017 Conference is Swinging back to democracy (Striving for institutional change in an ever-changing society). New, hybrid threats, devaluation of national sovereignty in favour of globalization, political radicalization and the evident disconnect of the majority from leading political elites are all clear indicators that our current era is steadily rendering our conventional political system obsolete. The need for change is apparent.
Topic: Settling the South China Sea dispute \n\nChairs: David Němeček, Daniel Ronen

Topic 1: Debating on freedom of religious expression in nations affected by terror attacks and/or threats 

Topic 2: Resolving cultural and logistical obstacles to contraceptives: promoting social and economic rights of women 

Chairs: Daniel Devereaux, Markéta Lišková
Topic: Cuban Missile Crisis: mediating a sustainable and mutually beneficial approach to protect peace and security \n\nChairs: Sebastian Štros, Natálie Vyhnalová
Topic: to be announced \n\nChairs: Miroslav Crha

Topic 1: Kurdistan: solving the issue of the largest nation without a sovereign territory


Topic 2: The future of refugees: the question of assimilation versus repatriation 

Chairs: Nina Pricová, Robin Zenker

Topic 1: Responsibility to protect: the past and the future of international efforts to prevent mass atrocities 

Topic 2: Overcoming the deadlock in defining and combatting international terrorism 

Chairs: Martin Bláha, Barbora Müllerová

Topic 1: Carbon offsetting and other innovative methods of reducing emissions while staying competitive 

Topic 2: Resource entitlement: defining the minimum environmental and financial conditions of fossil fuel exploitation by transnational corporations 

Chairs: Maxmilián Sup, Šimon Olmer

Topic 1: Strengthening African states by regionally shifting towards an export-based industrial economy focusing specifically on disadvantaged land-locked states 

Topic 2: Political crisis in Burundi: establishing a redistribution system for regional migrants and providing them with a social safety net 

Chairs: Bruce Bybee, Lucie Čapková

Topic 1: Sustainable agricultural and agronomic innovation for food self-suffiency of LDCs 

Topic 2: Personal transportation as a significant contributor to climate change: the strive for more affordable and efficient alternatives 

Chairs: Františka Tranová, Josef Bratršovský

Topic 1: Reevaluating the war on drugs and updating international legislation on illegal substances 

Topic 2: Transparent ownership one year after Panama papers 

Chairs: Daniella Ofer, Marek Gerle

Topic 1: Creating universal morality guidelines for research in the field of genetic modification of human embryos

Topic 2: Assuring women's health by globally promoting safe abortion procedures in cases of involuntary pregnancies arising from sexual violence

Chairs: Veronika Holubová, Anastasia Rybalchenko

Topic 1: Reducing the power of the drug lords and gangs and eliminating the negative social phenonemons appearing with drug trafficking and drug use 

Topic 2: Establishing unified counter-terrorism procedures in the aftermath of the recent terrorist attacks on UN member states 

Chairs: Nina Pricová, Adam Motloch

Points and motions are tools used to change the course of debate or to get recognized by the Chair. They cover a wide array of agenda and their knowledge is absolutely instrumental to fully participating in a debate. Below is a list of possible points and motions with explanations.

The Point of Information to the Chair may be raised by any Delegate when the Chair has the floor. The Point of Information shall not interrupt the Chair and the Delegate must wait to be recognized. The Point of Information to the Chair shall have the form of a question about the proceedings of the Session or a request for information concerning the Topic of the Debate.
The Point of Personal Privilege may be raised by any Delegate in case of personal discomfort. This Point shall not interrupt the Speaker unless it concerns their audibility.

The Point of Order may be raised by any Delegate. It may only refer to the order of proceedings or a violation of the Rules of Procedure, including the mistake of the Chair. This Point may interrupt the Speaker. The Delegate shall then explain the nature of their Point. It is to be evaluated by the Chair immediately.

The Right of Reply may only be raised by a Delegate that was mentioned by the Speaker in a manner they consider offending either personally or on behalf of their country. This Point may not interrupt the Speaker. The Chair may choose not to entertain this Point. Exclaiming “Right of Reply” along with raising the placard is acceptable when raising this Point. The Chair must rule on this point immediately. The Right of Reply shall consist of a short, mostly factual statement and may include a demand of an apology. The Speaker is then asked whether they wish to apologize.
Motion to move into voting procedure

The Motion to Move Directly into Voting Procedure may be raised by any Delegate and requires a Second. If any Delegate raises an Objection, the Motion is not in order. The Chair may choose not to entertain this Motion.
Motion to move into closed debate

The Motion to Move into Closed Debate may be raised by any Delegate during Open Debate. This Motion requires a Second. If any Delegate raises an Objection, the Motion is not in order. The Chair may choose not to entertain this Motion.

The Motion to Move into Unmoderated Caucus may be raised by any Delegate during Open Debate. This Motion requires a Second. If any Delegate raises an Objection, this Motion is not in order. The Chair may choose not to entertain this Motion. The Motion to Move into Unmoderated Caucus must specify the time for the Unmoderated Caucus.

If a Delegate wishes to give a speech during Open or Closed Debate, he may do so by raising his placard. The Chair may specify the time for individual speeches beforehand. We kindly ask the delegates to stand up when delivering their speech and always refer to themselves and other delegates in the third person. After a Delegate has finished his speech, he may open himself to Points of Information. When all Points of Information have been entertained, the Delegate must yield the floor back to the Chair.

Each Committee Topic with the exception of the Security Council and the Historical Security Council shall begin with a Lobbying Session, during which the Delegates are expected to work on Resolutions. During Lobbying Session, the Delegates are free to move around the room and compose the Resolutions to be submitted.

Resolutions shall be submitted to the Chairs by the Main Submitter of the Resolution. Each Resolution must have one Main Submitter and at least three Co-submitters. Main Submitter must present the Resolution and give a speech on it. Resolutions must be submitted in the proper United Nations format. Before a Resolution is debated upon in the Committee, it shall be revised by the Approval Panel, which may change the form, including grammar, wording and style, but not the substance of the Resolution. No Resolution shall be voted upon until all Delegates present have received a copy of it. When a Resolution is submitted, the Committee will enter into Open Debate on the Resolution.

In an Open Debate, any Delegate may either take the floor to give a speech by raising their placard, or propose an Amendment. If a Delegate wants to speak about the Resolution, they should raise their placard and only when Chair yielded the floor to them, they may speak. After having finished their speech, they may choose to open themselves to Points of Information. They may state whether they open themselves to “any and all” Points of Information, only to a certain number of Points of Information or no Points of Information. Delegates may also propose Amendments to either add a clause, strike a clause, or modify an existing one. If there are no more Motions or Amendments on the floor, the house will move into Closed Debate on the matter discussed (Amendment or Resolution).

Once there are no more delegates wishing to take the floor to speak about the Resolution, Amendment or Amendment to the 2nd degree or submit amendments during Open Debate, or when sufficient time has been spent debating the matter, the Chair will announce moving into a closed debate. During Closed Debate, one speech in favor and one against the Resolution or the Amendment or the Amendment to the 2nd degree will be entertained. After all the speeches and any potential Points of Information have been entertained the Committee will move into the voting procedure.

Each delegation is required to elect one Ambassador. Every Ambassador will be invited by the President of the General Assembly to give an Opening Speech during the General Assembly of the Opening Ceremony, summarizing their delegation\'s stance and goals for the upcoming Conference.

Delegates may submit Amendments to Amendments (Amendments to the 2nd Degree). If an Amendment to the 2nd Degree does not pass, the Committee shall proceed into open debate on the original Amendment. If the Amendment to the 2nd Degree passes, the original Amendment passes as well. Amendments to the Amendments to the 2nd Degree (Amendments to the 3rd Degree) shall not be entertained.

Delegates may not abstain from voting on Amendments and Amendments to the 2nd Degree. Decisions of Committees shall be made by a simple majority of Delegates present and voting. When an Amendment passes, it becomes a part of the draft Resolution.

In addition to Amendments, Delegates may also submit Friendly Amendments. Friendly Amendments may be submitted to Resolutions, Amendments or Amendments to the 2nd Degree. Friendly Amendments are not to be voted upon, they are to be agreed or disagreed to by the Main Submitter of the Resolution, Amendment or Amendment to the 2nd Degree. Friendly Amendments may change the form, but not the substance of the Resolution or Amendment.

The Chairs may specify at the beginning of Voting Procedure, whether the delegates will vote by raising their placards or by roll call. Unless specified, the vote will take place by raising placards. The Chair will ask all the delegates in favor to raise their placards, then those against and lastly, whether there were any abstentions. Delegates may abstain from voting on Resolutions but may not abstain from voting on Amendments or Amendments to the 2nd Degree. A simple majority of present and voting Delegates is required in all Voting Procedures. Delegates that abstain from voting are not considered present and voting.

The Chairs may specify at the beginning of Voting Procedure, whether the delegates will vote by raising their placards or by roll call. If the Voting Procedure is done by roll call, the Chair will ask each Delegate for their vote. The Delegates must respond with either \"in favor\", \"against\" or \"abstain\". Delegates may abstain from voting on Resolutions but may not abstain from voting on Amendments or Amendments to the 2nd Degree. A simple majority of present and voting Delegates is required in all Voting Procedures. Delegates that abstain from voting are not considered present and voting.

Each member of the Security Council shall have one vote. The five permanent members (P5 Member States) - the French Republic, the People\'s Republic of China, the Russian federation, the United States of America and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland shall have Veto rights. The P5 Member States shall hold Veto rights in all Voting Procedures. If one or more of the P5 Member States vote against the Resolution, Amendment or Amendment to the 2nd Degree, it shall not pass. Abstaining is not considered as vetoing. A simple majority of Delegates is required in all Voting Procedures.

11:00 - 13:00 Registration
13:00 - 16:30 Opening Ceremony
16:30 - 16:45 Supervisor Meeting 
19:00 - 21:00 Icebreakers (at Exe Iris Hotel)

09:00 - 17:00 Committees in session
12:00 - 14:00 Lunch
16:00 - 17:00 NGO presentations
19:00 - 20:00 Prague Tour (Meeting at St. Wenceslas Statue, Václavské náměstí)
* This event is organized by the PORGMUN team but without the supervision of Nový PORG and PORG Libeň schools.
